node.title: Refactor measure-time-taken-by-function from spread syntax to callback function
node.body:
I thought the spread syntax was kinda odd, so I opened this pull request to adopt the more common callback style. Discussion welcome.

One potential benefit of this is that the callback can be stored in a separate variable, allowing you to pass the variable to the function timeTaken() directly. You can also pass parameterless functions directly without wrapping them in another arrow function.

node.title: Fix: validateNumber: check cooercian
node.body:
now passes all 16 test cases:
```js
[
validateNumber('10') // true
,!validateNumber(false) // false
,!validateNumber(true) // false
,validateNumber(10) // true
,validateNumber(0.10) // true
,validateNumber(010) // true
,validateNumber(0xA) // true
,!validateNumber(NaN) // false
,!validateNumber(null) // false
,!validateNumber(undefined) // false
,!validateNumber('10%') // false, % is a construct
,!validateNumber('10px') // false
,!validateNumber(Infinity) // false
,validateNumber(Math.PI) // true, but is such an extreme edge case...
,validateNumber(0) // true, will probably wreck things
,validatenumber(1e10) // true
]
```

node.title: code error
fix/update intializeArrayWithRange.md
node.body:
## [BUG] update/fix initializeArrayWithRange

### Expected Snippet Behavior
Behavior should stay consistent. if `start = 0` and `0` gets mapped/initialized I believe `end` should also mapped/initailized like so. If both arguments are inclusive, or inclusive and/or exclusive I think it should say in the description. My assumption however is that the function arguments `start` and `end` are both inclusive 

```js
initializeArrayWithRange(5) //-> [0,1,2,3,4,5]
initializeArrayWithRange(7, 3) //-> [3,4,5,6,7]
```

<!--- If you're suggesting a change/improvement, tell us how it should work -->

### Current Snippet Behavior
However that is not the case and when the arrayRange gets initialized only the start is initialized with the array
```js
const initializeArrayWithRange = (end, start = 0) =>
  Array.from({ length: end - start }).map((v, i) => i + start);
// initializeArrayWithRange(5) -> [0,1,2,3,4]
// initializeArrayWithRange(7, 3) -> [3,4,5,6]
```
<!--- If suggesting a change/improvement, explain the difference from current behavior -->

### Possible Solution
Simple `(end + 1)` fix should do the trick
```js
const initializeArrayWithRange = (end, start = 0) =>
  Array.from({ length: (end + 1) - start }).map((v, i) => i + start);
// initializeArrayWithRange(5) -> [0,1,2,3,4,5]
// initializeArrayWithRange(7, 3) -> [3,4,5,6,7]

```
## *PR fix/Update*
### initializeArrayWithRange

Initializes an array containing the numbers in the specified range where `start` and `end` are inclusive.

Use `Array((end + 1) - start)` to create an array of the desired length, `Array.map()` to fill with the desired values in a range.
You can omit `start` to use a default value of `0`.

```js
const initializeArrayWithRange = (end, start = 0) => 
  Array.from({ length: (end + 1) - start }).map((v, i) => i + start);
// initializeArrayWithRange(5) -> [0,1,2,3,4,5]
// initializeArrayWithRange(7, 3) -> [3,4,5,6,7]
```

As described in #252

node.title: [FEATURE] Add select
node.body:
Add a `select `function that retrieves a property that indicated by the selector from object.

```js
const select = (from, selector) =>
  selector.split('.').reduce((prev, cur) => prev && prev[cur], from);

// const obj = {selector: {to: {val: 'val to select'}}};
// select(obj, 'selector.to.val'); -> 'val to select'
```

node.title: [UPDATE] pull.md -> merge pull.md & pullAll.md.
node.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

<!--- Add the prefix [FIX: #(issue number)] or [FEATURE] to the Title -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
**Resolves** #244 
> remove pullAll and update pull to work with any amount of values or an array, so we have a more general-use-case function without cluttering the list.

### pull

Mutates the original array to filter out the values specified.

Use `Array.filter()` and `Array.includes()` to pull out the values that are not needed.
Use `Array.length = 0` to mutate the passed in array by resetting it's length to zero and `Array.push()` to re-populate it with only the pulled values.

_(For a snippet that does not mutate the original array see [`without`](#without))_

```js
const pull = (arr, ...args) => {
  let pulled = arr.filter((v, i) => !args.toString().split(',').includes(v));
  arr.length = 0; pulled.forEach(v => arr.push(v));
};

// let myArray1 = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'a', 'b', 'c'];
// pull(myArray1, 'a', 'c');
// console.log(myArray1) -> [ 'b', 'b' ]

// let myArray2 = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'a', 'b', 'c'];
// pull(myArray2, ['a', 'c']);
// console.log(myArray2) -> [ 'b', 'b' ]
```

## Types of changes
- [ ] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)
- [x] Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to change)

node.title: [UPDATE] pull.md -> fix hacky approach
node.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

<!--- Add the prefix [FIX: #(issue number)], [FEATURE] or [ENHANCEMENT] to the Title -->

## [UPDATE] pull.md
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
**Resolves** #258  
### pull

Mutates the original array to filter out the values specified.

Use `Array.filter()` and `Array.includes()` to pull out the values that are not needed.
Use `Array.length = 0` to mutate the passed in array by resetting it's length to zero and `Array.push()` to re-populate it with only the pulled values.

_(For a snippet that does not mutate the original array see [`without`](#without))_

```js
const pull = (arr, ...args) => {
  let argState = Array.isArray(args[0]) ? args[0] : args;
  let pulled = arr.filter((v, i) => !argState.includes(v));
  arr.length = 0; 
  pulled.forEach(v => arr.push(v));
};

// let myArray1 = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'a', 'b', 'c'];
// pull(myArray1, 'a', 'c');
// console.log(myArray1) -> [ 'b', 'b' ]

// let myArray2 = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'a', 'b', 'c'];
// pull(myArray2, ['a', 'c']);
// console.log(myArray2) -> [ 'b', 'b' ]
```

node.title: [FEATURE] reduced Filter
node.body:
Filter an array of objects based on condition and return array with reduced objects.

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
This function utility is using ES6 Array.reduce() in order to filter an array with objects based on condition.
If condition is met, then Array.reduce is used again to construct object with the predefined properties. Further more, in order to dynamically evaluate condition based in object properties, item must be passed through window to Function constructor. Finally, when new object is constructed then it is saved in the output array.

node.title: Fix documentation for shuffle
node.body:
The implementation of `shuffle` was changed from an in-place function into a pure function, but the documentation was not updated, so I've updated the docs to mention that it returns a new array instead of shuffling the input in place.

Follow-up to https://github.com/Chalarangelo/30-seconds-of-code/pull/358

node.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

<!--- Add the prefix [FIX: #(issue number)], [FEATURE] or [ENHANCEMENT] to the Title -->

## Description

I'm happy to see the `clampNumber` snippet get added to this wonderful collection of snippets - it's a bit of code that I've been using for years. However, the versions of this snippet represented here seemed overly verbose or complicated. This PR distills the method, in my opinion, to its simplest form.

## What does your PR belong to?

node.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

<!--- Add the prefix [FIX: #(issue number)], [FEATURE] or [ENHANCEMENT] to the Title -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
Normalizes our script code formatting with our prettier settings

- defaults +
- print-width: 100
- single-quotes

There are still inconsistencies which certain code style choices, but this is a start.

Also rename the scripts without `-script` since it's redundant (they're within the `scripts/` dir). And remove start, because I think @Chalarangelo said it wasn't needed anymore. Correct me if I'm wrong.

node.body:

<!--- Add the prefix [FIX: #(issue number)], [FEATURE] or [ENHANCEMENT] to the Title -->

## tdd Script Update
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
run `npm run tdd` -> to generate TDD environment  
run `npm test`  -> to run all test created for all snippets

### *Version 0.0.2*

#### *layout/outline*
**1.** Create a `test/` dir if one doesn't already doesn't exist
**2.** Create a dir/folder | `snippetName/` for each snippet name with the following format
- `snippetName/snippetName.js` -> the snippet will be exported to the test file for testing  [creates seperation of concerns]
- import/require said snippets
#### If ( `snippetName/snippetName.test.js` doesn't exist) {
- Create `snippetName/snippetName.test.js` & set up 4 different example test that are commented out with a commented out link to all the other methods made available by tape & 1 test testing if snippet is a function

#### }

<!--- Add the prefix [FIX: #(issue number)], [FEATURE] or [ENHANCEMENT] to the Title -->

## Description

- Allows for autopluralization with currying
- Allows any number. `-1` and `1` are considered "singular". Actually should -1 be plural? I don't really know. It doesn't make sense to pluralize negatives, but I feel like it shouldn't throw an error at all. It also coerces strings etc to a number to make life easier.

node.title: Add binarySearch
node.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

<!--- Add the prefix [FIX: #(issue number)], [FEATURE] or [ENHANCEMENT] to the Title -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->

### binarySearch

Use recursion to perform a logarithmic search similar to `.indexOf()` that finds the index of a value within an array. The two differences being 
1. Opperation only works with sorted arrays
2. Offers a major performance boost when compared liner search or `.indexOf()` 

```js
const binarySearch = (array, value, start = 0, end = array.length - 1) => {
  if (start > end) {
    return -1;
  }

  let middle = Math.floor((start + end) / 2);
  let value = array[middle];

  if (value > value) {
      return binarySearch(array, value, start, middle-1);
  }
  if (value < value) {
    return binarySearch(array, value, middle+1, end);
  }
  return middle;
}
```

```js
binarySearch([1, 4, 6, 7, 12, 13, 15, 18, 19, 20, 22, 24], 6); // 2
```

node.title: [ENHANCEMENT] [UPDATE: `flip.md`] Use idiomatic js for flip function
node.body:
## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->

Used idiomatic javascript to avoid complex array functions. The rest operator is used to collect all the remaining argument of the function. So instead of taking the whole list and then popping the first element (this is expensive), we simply retain the first argument as a variable `first` and the rest of the arguments are stored as array in `rest` variable. Then we just change the order of arguments.

I think this code is easy to grok and is much faster and more ES6.

```js
const flip = fn => (first, ...rest) => fn(...rest, first);
```

Note - 
Intentionally used the word `rest` instead of `args` because I felt for this case rest better helps people understand that , rest holds all the args after first arg. If I have used `args` then it partly implies that first is not an arg which is not true
[flip function](https://30secondsofcode.org/#flip)

node.title: [FIX: #564] Fix inaccurate tomorrow() function
node.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

<!--- Add the prefix [FIX: #(issue number)], [FEATURE] or [ENHANCEMENT] to the Title -->

## Description
Fix a problem due to the assumption that days are always 24 hours long, while due to DST one day a year is 23 hours and one day a year is 25 hours long. This lead this function to give the current date during one hour a year and the day after tomorrow for another hour a year.

Additionally, the function only worked correctly when the user was in the same timezone as UTC. For example in Amsterdam which 1 hour from DST it only worked 23 hours a day. And in Sydney which is 11 hours away from DST, the function only worked correctly for 13 hours each day. During the hours it didn't work correctly it would give the current date instead of tomorrows.

<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
**Resolves** #564  <!--- Delete if not a issue fix-->

node.title: Add toCurrency
node.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

<!--- Add the prefix [FIX: #(issue number)], [FEATURE] or [ENHANCEMENT] to the Title -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
### toCurrency

Take a number and return specified currency formatting.

Use `new Intl.NumberFormat` to enable country / currency sensitive formatting.

```js
const toCurrency = (n, curr, LanguageFormat = undefined) => new Intl.NumberFormat(LanguageFormat, { style: 'currency', currency: curr }).format(n);
```

```js
toCurrency(123456.789, 'EUR') // €123,456.79  | currency: Euro | currencyLangFormat: Local
toCurrency(123456.789, 'USD', 'en-us') // €123,456.79  | currency: US Dollar | currencyLangFormat: English (United States)
toCurrency(123456.789, 'USD', 'fa') // ۱۲۳٬۴۵۶٫۷۹ ؜$ | currency: US Dollar | currencyLangFormat: Farsi
toCurrency(322342436423.2435, 'JPY') // ¥322,342,436,423 | currency: Japanese Yen | currencyLangFormat: Local
toCurrency(322342436423.2435, 'JPY', 'fi') // 322 342 436 423 ¥ | currency: Japanese Yen | currencyLangFormat: Finnish
```

node.title: [FEATURE][ADD] pipeAsyncFunctions
node.body:
## New Snippet `pipeAsyncFunctions`

I'm adding a new function similar to the `pipeFunctions` one but for Promises i.e can be used for asynchronous code:

```js
const pipeAsyncFunctions = (...fns) => arg => fns.reduce((p, f) => p.then(f), Promise.resolve(arg));
```

```js
const sum = pipeAsyncFunctions(
  x => x + 1,
  x => new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(() => resolve(x + 2), 1000)),
  x => x + 3,
  async x => (await x) + 4
);
(async () => {
  console.log(await sum(5)); // 15 (after one second)
})();
```

node.title: [FEATURE][ADD] Add stableSort function
node.body:
## New Snippet `stableSort`

Most browser engines support stable sorting via `Array.sort()` but not Chrome/NodeJS.

More information:
- [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sorting_algorithm#Stability)
- [Example](https://github.com/mziccard/node-timsort/#stability)
- [Implementation](https://gist.github.com/simov/aa3b9e534039fa00ac3c1b4905605069)

Example wrapper utils as well.

```js
// Assumes checking fn1 is more performant than fn2
const isMorePerformant = (fn1, fn2) => mostPerformant([fn1, fn2]) === 0
```

For increased reliability, you might want to check the most frequent index when doing `mostPerformant` calls multiple times (along with high iteration count)

node.title: [WEB] Avoid forced reflows inside search function
node.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

<!--- Add the prefix [FIX: #(issue number)], [FEATURE] or [ENHANCEMENT] to the Title -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
This PR improves the performance of the snippet search function on the website. The `search` was running slowly (~1 second per `keyup` event) due to forced reflows caused by alternating style reads and writes for each iteration of its internal loops. For example, on each iteration through the loop of snippet nodes, there was a style read due to calling `x.innerText` on a DOM node, then a style write due to `x.style.display = ...`. This forced a reflow on each time through the loop, slowing down the total time taken to search through all nodes for matches. This profile depicts one call of `search` with the argument `"if"` prior to the fix.

![before](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12390642/37302278-ac1918ea-25f0-11e8-814a-63761c2665bc.jpeg)

Instead, replacing `x.innerText` with `x.textContent` avoids forced reflows and allows the browser to batch all style updates when the loop finishes. This profile shows the same call to `search` as above, but without the intermediate reflows:

![after](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12390642/37302485-4af49ea8-25f1-11e8-99b6-7a6fadbf6283.jpeg)

I found that this change removed the noticeable delay between typing a character and seeing the updated list of results.

node.title: Add when()
node.body:
Inspired by [Ramda](http://ramdajs.com/docs/#when), I absolutely love this function. It's even better, however, if you compose it by only supplying the first two parameters.

That's why my implementation returns a function expecting `x`.

If accepted, would we consider currying this function? I think the answer's "no" based on [previous discussion](https://github.com/Chalarangelo/30-seconds-of-code/pull/646#issuecomment-380253755) that this is a learning library.

node.title: Add reject
node.body:
`Array.filter`'s complement. Whatever `filter` keeps, `reject` denies.

This repo's a great functional programming resource, but I surprisingly haven't encountered complementary functions yet. Maybe I haven't look hard enough, but it'd still be cool to contribute this 😁 .

node.title: add InitializeOrderedArray
node.body:
## Description

### InitializeOrderedArray

A thing I've found myself using a LOT recently to create a ordered array. Very useful for start arrays with values.

## How to use

```js
const initializeArrayWithValues = (n) => [...(Array(n).keys())];

initializeArrayWithValues(5); // [0,1,2,3,4]
```

<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

<!--- Add the prefix [FIX: #(issue number)], [FEATURE] or [ENHANCEMENT] to the Title -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
I have simplified the rearg snippet so that it's easier to understand in 30 seconds.  

The simplified version is also more powerful - it now also support duplication of arguments & extension in the number of arguments.  I didn't add tests/examples for this new functionality (yet) since I wasn't sure if we would want to commit to these additional features in the future.

node.title: [ENHANCEMENT] Optimized Longest Item function
node.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

<!--- Add the prefix [FIX: #(issue number)], [FEATURE] or [ENHANCEMENT] to the Title -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
Changed longestItem function to run in O(n) rather than O(nlog(n)).
Note: The longest item returned will now be the last one in the array rather than an unspecified one (since Array.sort is not necessarily stable).

node.title: [REFACTOR/ENHANCEMENT] Refactor + Simplify Builder
node.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

<!--- Add the prefix [FIX: #(issue number)], [FEATURE] or [ENHANCEMENT] to the Title -->

## Description
The builder scripts of our projects have always been a bit messy, especially the ones of this project. To make the generators more dynamic, readable and shorter, I've been working on a dependency-free, lightweight node markdown builder recently, exclusively for the 30-seconds projects, see it [here](https://github.com/flxwu/markdown-builder).

I also fixed the [isSimilar snippet](https://github.com/Chalarangelo/30-seconds-of-code/tree/master/snippets_archive#issimilar) that currently is a bit messed up because of inconsistent line breaks.

README's should basically be same except for indentation:
**Main README**: https://github.com/Chalarangelo/30-seconds-of-code/tree/refactor-builder
**Archive README**: https://github.com/Chalarangelo/30-seconds-of-code/tree/refactor-builder/snippets_archive

node.title: Avoid confusing prototype methods for static methods
node.body:
This repository confuses static methods such as `Array.from` with prototype methods such as `Array.prototype.join` by describing them using the same notation:

- `Array.from` (correct)
- `Array.join` (incorrect/confusing)

This patch uses the common `#` notation to denote `.prototype.`:

- `Array.from`
- `Array#join`

node.title: [FIX] Packager script: Babel 7, named exports
node.body:
<!-- Use a descriptive title, prefix it with [FIX], [FEATURE] or [ENHANCEMENT] if applicable (use only one) -->

## Description
The packager script was broken in several ways:

- `...` object rest spread operator in `nest.md` (now part of ES2018) was breaking Babel 6 without a transform plugin. Babel 7 works
- Exports were not named and could not be imported like: `import { snippet } from '30-seconds-of-code'`
- `dist` directory should be ignored in the repo and only published to npm

node.title: [FEATURE] Adding Heron's formula for area of any triangle
node.body:
Heron's Formula for Area of any (valid) triangle.

## Description
Adding heronArea.js and adding the corresponding entry in tag_database. More info on Heron's formula (and why it works) here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heron%27s_formula. This is exceptionally helpful for simplifying any math being done inside your JS, and abstracts away any altitude calculations being done before the (1/2)bh calculation often used instead.

node.title: [SCRIPTS] Packaging and testing updates
node.body:
As discussed in #816, here's what I've worked on so far:

- Merged `module.js` and `rollup.js` into one script. Minor performance increase (8.3s -> 7.8s). 
- Updated `module.js` to cut down the number of I/O operations. Reasonable performance increase (7.8s -> 5.1s).
- Updated `module.js` to output a full (snippets + archive) `_30s.js` file in `test`. Negligible performance impact.
- Made `module.js` skip bundles when running on non-CRON/API builds. Performance for the test package seems to be ~52ms on my machine, which should be pretty good for running tests on commits.
- Updated `tdd.js` to follow the structure discussed above, updated all `.test.js` files, fixed a few failing tests, cleaned up orphaned tests etc. Overall performance is about the same, maybe we managed to earn ourselves a second or two.

node.title: [SCRIPTS] ESLint (finally)
node.body:
As discussed in #816, here's the linting subsystem rebuilt:

- Added `eslint` to the `devDependencies`.
- Configured `.eslintrc.json` to enforce our coding style.
- Swapped out `semistandard`, as `eslint` does the same job that it did.
- Updated `lint.js` to use `eslint` (some rules are overriden there in order to deal with all the problematic data that comes from generated files).
- Made `eslint` `--fix` errors on its own in the `linter` process and give us a report (that does not seem to auto-commit from CI builds, that's probably for the best).
- Run the new `linter` on pretty much everything, some rules are now better applied across the board.

**Only thing remaining** is to configure Codacy to use this ruleset from now on and we are golden.

node.title: [FEATURE] add isNegativeZero
node.body:
## Description

I've added a handy utility snippet that checks whether a provided value is negative zero or not. 

Before you make a noise, let me explain a bit how JavaScript handles numbers and why is this function useful to some people.

#### JavaScript 0 and -0 examples
```js
0 === -0 //  true
0 / 3 // equals to 0
0 / -3 // equals to  -0

Infinity === -Infinity // false
```
Yes. I know that negative zero doesn't exist in real Math but this is just how JavaScript engine threats it. Whenever JavaScript engine works with dividing negatives, it treats them as positives and adds `-` afterward.

#### Usage
Not much as you've guessed it but this function can be used when writing complex animations, a `-0` on just finished animation can provide information on whether the animation was coming from the right or the left side etc. 

#### Note about tests
I wrote the tests, they don't pass due to the way they work. In order to make them work the `_30s` needs `isNegativeZero` module in it. (I've tested manually and they do work).

node.title: [FEATURE] chainAsync update: last function shouldn't get 'next' as argument
node.body:
## Description
chainAsync update: last function shouldn't get 'next' as argument. That way it's easier to add a condition within the functions to check whether they're the last one, e.g. `if(next){/* is last function*/}else{/* isn't */}`. This is useful when the array of functions is generated, rather than hard-coded.

My tests pass, but the `npm` scripts outlined in the docs didn't update `test/_30.js`. Not sure what additional step is needed for that.

node.title: [ENHANCEMENT] Replace double-quote characters in CSV fields
node.body:
Hi everyone! :-)

## Description
As CSV fields are wrapped in double quotes by default, double-quote characters should also be replaced with pairs of quotes which is more or less the standard way to handle these. I was also thinking about an optional escape character argument, but didn't want to over-engineer it at this point.

node.title: [FIX] #907 Explain next tick logic on `hashNode`
node.body:
It was something we forgot and that we don't want to forget. Sending it onto the event loop prevents us from blocking with a long operation, allowing other things on the event loop to happen before a take a possibly long time

Resolves #907 

<!-- Use a descriptive title, prefix it with [FIX], [FEATURE] or [ENHANCEMENT] if applicable (use only one) -->

## Description
We push the hashing onto the next tick and use a promise because the hash could take a long time to complete.

node.title: Update README.md for Open Collective
node.body:
Hi, I'm making updates for Open Collective. Either you or a supporter signed this repo up for Open Collective. This pull request adds backers and sponsors from your Open Collective https://opencollective.com/30-seconds-of-code-653❤️

It adds two badges at the top to show the latest number of backers and sponsors. It also adds placeholders so that the avatar/logo of new backers/sponsors can automatically be shown without having to update your README.md. [more info](https://github.com/opencollective/opencollective/wiki/Github-banner). See how it looks on this [repo](https://github.com/apex/apex#backers).

You can also add a postinstall script to let people know after npm|yarn install that you are welcoming donations (optional). [More info](https://github.com/OpenCollective/opencollective-cli)
You can also add a "Donate" button to your website and automatically show your backers and sponsors there with our widgets. Have a look here: https://opencollective.com/widgets

P.S: As with any pull request, feel free to comment or suggest changes. The only thing "required" are the placeholders on the README because we believe it's important to acknowledge the people in your community that are contributing (financially or with code!).

Thank you for your great contribution to the open source community. You are awesome! 🙌
And welcome to the open collective community! 😊

Come chat with us in the #opensource channel on https://slack.opencollective.com - great place to ask questions and share best practices with other open source sustainers!

node.title: [ENHANCEMENT] arrayToCSV escape quotes in strings and un-quote numeric vals
node.body:
## Description
Most CSV parsers understand strings to be wrapped in double quotes, and double-quotes within strings to be escaped with additional double quotes. In addition, values not enclosed in quotes should be interpreted as numeric.
This modifies the existing one-liner to provide this functionality. The function should now produce a CSV that can be parsed by any compliant reader for just about any kind of input.

## PR Type

node.title: Update createDirIfNotExists function
node.body:
<!-- Use a descriptive title, prefix it with [FIX], [FEATURE] or [ENHANCEMENT] if applicable (use only one) -->

## Description
Modified `createDirIfNotExists` snippet. Now it is asynchronous and safe. Those reasons are attached in the snippet description:

```
Using fs.exists() to check for the existence of a directory before calling fs.mkdir() is not recommended. 
Doing so introduces a race condition, since other processes may change the directory's state between the two calls. 
Instead, user code should create the directory directly and handle the error raised if the directory does not exist.

Why not fs.mkdirSync? In busy processes, the programmer is strongly encouraged to use the asynchronous versions of these calls. 
The synchronous versions will block the entire process until they complete — halting all connections.
```

Also, updated `module.js` script. It didn't want to work with multiple `require`

node.title: [ENHANCEMENT] Properly configure eslint to work with jest
node.body:
<!-- Use a descriptive title, prefix it with [FIX], [FEATURE] or [ENHANCEMENT] if applicable (use only one) -->

## Description
The current configuration is not making eslint aware that we are using jest. It has only the `test` global implicitly setup in the *globals* section.

A better way to do this is to enable the jest [environment option](https://eslint.org/docs/user-guide/configuring#specifying-environments).

Jest provides a lot of useful globals that are ready to use. For example, the `expect` function, it is currently required by all the 372 test files. This is not necessary.

The jest environment option for eslint supports out of the box all the available globals (`test`, `it`, `describe`, etc)...

This PR also changes *scripts/tdd.js* to remove the requiring of the `expect` function when creating *undefined test files*

<!-- Write a detailed description of your changes/additions here -->
<!-- If your PR resolves an issue, please state "Resolves #(issue number)" to help maintainers process it faster -->

node.title: fix(tests): expectations of some async test where not working
node.body:
<!-- Use a descriptive title, prefix it with [FIX], [FEATURE] or [ENHANCEMENT] if applicable (use only one) -->

## Description
Some expectations involving asynchronous tests were not working. By default, Jest tests complete once they reach the end of their execution. If there are assertions on asynchronous code, but we don't make Jest aware of it, those tests will simply pass.

There are specific ways to make Jest wait for expectations:

For callback-based code, we can introduce the `done` argument on each test. This is a callback function provided by Jest. Each test will wait for this callback to be executed after the desired assertions are done. If the `done` callback is not invoked, the test will timeout.

For promise-based code, we can simply return the promise from the test and use run the expectations on the `then`. Or we can use the `resolves` / `rejects` helpers.

Finally, we can use also async / await, by making the test closure async, and using await get the values to do the expectations.

More details about this on the [official docs](https://jestjs.io/docs/en/asynchronous).
 
<!-- Write a detailed description of your changes/additions here -->
<!-- If your PR resolves an issue, please state "Resolves #(issue number)" to help maintainers process it faster -->

node.title: Use 30-seconds-starter template
node.body:
As you might have noticed, for the past month I have been working on a [common template for 30 seconds repositories](https://github.com/30-seconds/30-seconds-starter). 

This PR updates the repository structure, snippets, scripts, etc. to use the common template as the first step in rolling out a universal-ish look, feel and structure for all repos under the organization.

**This is still a work in progress, do not merge unless I explicitly say so!**

### Completed tasks

- [x] Updated snippet format
- [x] Updated glossary format
- [x] Updated package
- [x] Updated extractor
- [x] Updated builder
- [x] Updated packager
- [x] Evaluated tester
- [x] Evaluated vscoder
- [x] Imported and configured webber
- [x] Updated guidelines, static content and git info
- [x] Evaluate performance issues on the website, especially on the list page, fix as necessary
- [x] Update website to host archived snippets
- [x] Update website to host the beginner page as before
- [x] Update website to host the glossary
- [x] Configure Google Analytics on website
- [x] Check with @petrovicstefanrs how this will affect 30-seconds-of-knowledge plugin
- [x] Run `npm audit fix`, resolve security vulnerabilities

### Remaining tasks

- [x] Setup Netlify, move away from Cloudflare and GitHub Pages (expect ~2 hours website downtime)

Due to the sheer amount of files changed, I would like some feedback from the team and community to iron out any remaining issues before migrating to this new structure.

node.title: [FIX] Update hasKey snippet to handle failing scenario and add new tests
node.body:
<!-- Use a descriptive title, prefix it with [FIX], [FEATURE] or [ENHANCEMENT] if applicable (use only one) -->

## Description
<!-- Write a detailed description of your changes/additions here -->
[hasKey](https://github.com/30-seconds/30-seconds-of-code#haskey) snippet is really handy to check for inner keys in nested objects. Unfortunately current implementation of it fails for a particular case:
(Where one key is prefix of another and it has object value, in this case `b` & `b.c`)
```
let obj = {
  'a': 1,
  'b': { 'e': 4 },
  'b.c': 5
};

hasKey(obj, 'b.c');
// should return "true" but returns "false"
```

The above scenario can not be handled with current method signature of accepting second argument as string. Using function signature where it accepts Array of keys, we can address above scenario along with other simpler cases.

This also simplifies overall implementation of function without using any recursion or string manipulations. With Array as key list, we can use `Array.prototype.every()` to simplify and early return on failure.

---

<!-- If your PR resolves an issue, please state "Resolves #(issue number)" to help maintainers process it faster -->
This PR updates [hasKey](https://github.com/30-seconds/30-seconds-of-code#haskey) snippet to handle this failing cases along with existing ones and simplifies overall implementation of the function.
<!-- If you think your PR will cause breaking changes, require changes in the documentation etc, please be so kind as to explain what, where and how -->
This changes signature of [hasKey](https://github.com/30-seconds/30-seconds-of-code#haskey) snippet to accept list of strings instead of just a string, which can be called as a breaking change.


## PR Type

<!-- If you think your PR will cause breaking changes, require changes in the documentation etc, please be so kind as to explain what, where and how -->

Just a small change but I discovered that the variable i isn't used in 
```javascript
let pulled = arr.filter((v, i) => !argState.includes(v));
```
so I changed the line to 
```javascript
let pulled = arr.filter(v => !argState.includes(v));
```

node.title: [ENHANCEMENT]: Improve description, examples, and tests of 'remove'
node.body:
## Description

The current description and examples of the `remove` function is confusing at best. It was originally inspired by the lodash `remove` function: https://github.com/30-seconds/30-seconds-of-code/pull/148

However, from the description and examples it is not really clear that remove actually mutates the original array. I've updated the description and the examples to reflect better what is actually happening.

node.title: [FIX] Correctly implement luhnCheck
node.body: ## Description Resolves #1084. As explained in the issue, the `acc + ((val * 2) % 9) || 9)` logic in the function makes it so if even if the acc should equal zero it gets set to 9, which messes up the rest of the calculation. You can see this happening here: ## PR Type - [x] Snippets, Tests & Tags (new snippets, updated snippets, re-tagging of snippets, added/updated tests) - [ ] Tools, Scripts & Automation (anything related to files in the scripts folder, Gatsby, website, Travis CI or Netlify) - [ ] General, Typos, Misc. & Meta (everything related to content, typos, general stuff and meta files in the repository - e.g. the issue template) - [ ] Other (please specify in the description above) ## Guidelines - [x] I have read the guidelines in the [CONTRIBUTING](https://github.com/30-seconds/30-seconds-of-code/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) document. **PLEASE NOTE:** I wasn't able to find out how to properly update `_30s.es5.min.js`, every tool I used ending up adding extra quotes that would have changed a lot of the file rather than just the `luhnCheck` function. If someone could help me out with that it'd be great.

node.title: Fix issue #1175 and cater additional scenarios
node.body:
**The Issue(s)**

As shared in [issue#1175](https://github.com/30-seconds/30-seconds-of-code/issues/1175). The current code fails to restore nested properties and doesnot cater for scenairos like
```js
unflattenObject({ 'a.b': 1, 'a.c': 2, d: 3 })
unflattenObject({ 'a.b': 'foo', d: 3 })
```
where either the same key is being refered more than once or the values are non numbers. More detials can be seen in [this](https://runkit.com/tbasse/5f2a9929c9b5c9001a4d3a6e) runkit shared in the issue as well.

An additional scenario which the code failed to handle was when the flat path reffered to particular indices in the arrays values against a key. For example.
```js
unflattenObject({ 'a.b.0': 5, d: 3 })
```
should return something like `{a:{b:[5]}, d: 3}`. However, the code fails to compile.


**Solution**

I fixed the snippet to handle these scenarios along with some improvements. The updated code which passes all these tests can be seen in [this](https://runkit.com/taimoor0217/unflattenobject) runkit.

**Modifications / Improvements**

The previous code uses `JSON.parse()` to parse the manually built string into JSON and then merges it with the accumulator using `Object.assign()`. This happened for ever iteration of `Array.prototype.reduce()`. My code takes a slightly different approach of making the reference to the values as the next accumulator. This ways, I can directly mutate and nested objects without having to merge on each iteration. This arguably improves the performance fo the code.

Javascript array remove
node.body:
This pull request:

- renames the JavaScript array remove snippet to removeAll (this is what that snippet actually does)
- adds a type safe, ES6 compliant removePrimitive Array.prototype method that safely extends the native prototype

This method has been thoroughly tested - tests for this method can be found [here](https://github.com/GrayedFox/multidict/blob/master/test/globals.spec.js).

The method is named `remove` in the tests however the code being tested in that repository is [nearly identical](https://github.com/GrayedFox/multidict/blob/master/src/globals.js).

Thanks for the great repository and service! Neat idea 👍🏾

node.title: Update: Increase the speed of the algorithm
node.body:
Hi,

I think that the speed of the algorithm can be increased by several orders of magnitude with the change I am proposing.

The old algorithm has an average complexity of O(n^2) because ```Array.prototype.some()``` and ```Array.prototype.filter()```methods are being used inside a ```for of``` loop.

The new algorithm first converts the larger array into an object (hash map). Then the smaller array is iterated on with a lookup search on the hashMap object.

The worst case complexity of the new algorithm is O(n).

[isContainedInOld vs isContainedInNew](https://perf.link/#%%)

I also updated the documentation and added new example cases.

Improve mapObject snippet
node.body:
Improve `mapObject` snippet to be able to map arrays containing objects to an object.

Example: 

```js
mapObject(
  [
    { name: "key1", someBoolean: true },
    { name: "key2", someBoolean: false },
  ],
  (el) => el.someBoolean,
  (el) => el.name
); // { key1: true, key2: false }
```

node.title: Add new snippet ( generateUniqueString )
node.body:
---
title: generateUniqueString
tags: string,random,unique,intermediate
---

Generate unique string

- Use `Math.prototype.random` to create a random number
- Use `Number.prototype.toString` and pass `16` as radix parameter to convert number to hexadecimal number 
- Use `String.prototype.slice` to skip first two characters because `Number.prototype.toString` will return `0.<number>`

```js
const generateUniqueString = () => Math.random().toString(16).slice(2)
```

```js
generateUniqueString(); // f3c9049d08d34
```

node.title: add toHSLObject
node.body:
In addition to [this PR](https://github.com/30-seconds/30-seconds-of-code/pull/1616) that adds `toHSLArray` I am adding a utility function to restructure it inside an object. 

I went with full `hsl` "component" names _(hue, saturation, lightness)_ due to code readability and use cases. For example, it would be much cleaner to say `lightness * 0.5` to make it darker than doing `l * 0.5` etc. PS I also vote we do this to [`toRGBObject`](https://www.30secondsofcode.org/js/s/to-rgb-object).

Anyways to celebrate 2000 followers on our Twitter bot we made a year ago, I got this Greek candy:

node.title: Update takeWhile.md
node.body: The definition of take while seems inverted. When you use `takeWhile()`, what you really say is: out of these array elements `[1, 2, 3, 4]`, take (keep selecting) elements while an element (`n`) is less than 3.  Earlier example `takeWhile([1, 2, 3, 4], n => n >= 3);` was less intuitive as you are asking for elements greater than equal to 3 but actually expect `[1, 2]` in t=return.

node.title: Make Changes in project to solve issues #1861
node.body:
I make changes so that overall project files makes more readable and appealing to learn. 
- like 'I' in but to make code more readable we need to make the 'leftIndex in the binary Search file.
- like 2d matrix calculation generally used i , j for row and col but can we make this to row for i and j for the column so that code makes it more readable.
- Instead of using 'el' in a file using an element in that file or any other file that 'el'. 
- like 'r' in but to make code more readable we need to make the 'rightIndex' in the binary Search file. 
- Instead of using the 'val' for storing value can be used to 'value'. 
- Instead of using 'c' for storing character can we used 'character'. 
- Need to add some more files for Node modules 
- Console.count() method is used to count the length of the specified label 
- Need to make changes in some of the major files.
- Console.count() method is used to count the length of the specified label 
- path.dirname() method is used to get the string path for a specified file.
- Binary Search is used to make the searching from linear time complexity to logarithm. 
- path.dirname() method provides utility for working with file and directory paths. 
- default operation of the path module varies from operating system on which node application is running. like when node application on windows operating system it assume that windows based path are used. 
- path.dirname() is similar to `` dirname ``  in UNIX-based operating system.

node.title: add parseJWT to get object
node.body:
Decode the payload of JWT using JavaScript, without using a library or the `jwt.io` site. The token just returns a payload object that can consumed by your front-end code.
- Use `String.prototype.split('.')[1]` to extract the Base64Url encoded second part of the JSON Web Token.
- Then base64 decode it, using `decodeURIComponent()` and the `atob` functions to finally get the stringified JSON.
- Use the parsed Object by returning the `JSON.parse()` of the output.
